headline.main: THE AFFAIR BELOW NEW-ORLEANS.; THE CRUISE OF THE McCLELLAN. INTERESTING NARRATIVE OF AN OFFICER ON BOARD.

docs.lead_paragraph: Having been repeatedly asked for a report of the cruise of the S.S. McClellan, and our assertions of the fact that we were of some practical use being dimly and very vaguely hinted at in the official report from the mouth not of the Passes, I have concluded to give you a succinct account of our doings for the last six weeks.

docs.snippet: The following private letter has been placed in our hands, which gives in detail the recapture of Lexington, and the rescue of Cols. WHITE and GROVER from the hands of the rebels.

headline.main: AFFAIRS IN MISSOURI.; THE RECAPTURE OF LEXINGTON. INSTRUCTIONS TO BRITISH CONSULS. DESTRUCTION OF THE THOMAS WATSON. THE BLOCKADE OF CHARLESTON. DOINGS OF THE ROANOKE CHANGES OF OFFICERS CAPTURE OF A PRIZE RFCONNOITERING THE HARBOR. FROM THE NORTH CAROLINA COAST. THE GOODS ORPERED FROM EUROPE. LATER FROM THE SOUTH. AN ESCAPE. FROM MANASSAS. THE ENGAGEMENT AT EVANSPORT. AFFAIRS IN KENTUCKY. THE QUESTION OF NEGRO CONFISCATION. CHAPEL TENTS IN THE ARMY. DESTRUCTION OF THE TERRE HAUTE JOURNAL OFFICE. MOVEMENTS OF TROOPS IN CALIFORNIA. THE ORDERS FOR FOREIGN CLOTH.

headline.main: THE GREAT REBELLION.; Further Particulars of the Fight Near Leesburgh Gallant Conduct of the National Troops. GEN. McCLELLAN UP THE RIVER. Our Army Ready to Occupy Leesburgh. Probability of an Advance To-day. Preparations for the Obsequies ofCol. Baker. THE LOWER POTOMAC STILL CLOSED. Unsuccessful Attempts to Pass the Blockade. Rebel Troops Leaving Kentucky for New-Orleans and Mobile. A Series of Skirmishes in Missouri VIENNA EVACUATED BY THE REBELS. A DETACHMENT OF THE MOZART MEN SURPRISED. THE NEW BATTERIES AT MATTHIAS POINT. THE STEAMER HUGH JENKINS RAISED. PASSING THE BATTERIES. ATTEMPT TO PASS THE BATTERIES. A DECISION AFFECTING MERCHANTS. THE CASE OF JUDGE MERRICK. THE BLOCKADE. AFFAIRS ALONG THE LINES. ARMY APPOINTMENTS. THE HOSPITAL REPORTS. DEATH OF ASHBURY DICKENS. COL. GRAHAM NOT KILLED.
